dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Fintiv, the social media giant, is suing Apple, right? But their past as Mondo is just wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fintiv, the social media giant, is suing Apple, right? But their past as Mondo is just wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Based in Austin, Texas, Fintiv is a virtually unknown entity in the tech world, describing itself as being in the business of mobile payments and marketing campaigns. But Fintiv used to be known by a different name, Mozido, a once-hot mobile payments startup at the center of a large alleged investment fraud and criminal prosecution.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. Mondo, that was the mobile payments company with all the fraud, wasn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. Mondo, that was the mobile payments company with all the fraud, wasn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Fintiv used to be known by a different name, Mozido, a once-hot mobile payments startup at the center of a large alleged investment fraud and criminal prosecution.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, over 500 investors got defrauded according to the SEC. And CEO Adolfo Salume admitted to it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, over five hundred investors got defrauded according to the S E C. And C E O Adolfo Salume admitted to it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Charlie Wiggs, president of Fintiv, signed the Delaware filing changing Mozidos name to Fintiv a few days after the Securities & Exchange Commission charged Liberty last year of defrauding 200 individual investors. He said Fintivs policy is to not comment on the criminal and regulatory actions against Michael Liberty.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, and then they had that CFO, Michael Liberty, who was accused of diverting funds for personal use. That's just… wow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, and then they had that C F O, Michael Liberty, who was accused of diverting funds for personal use. That's just... wow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In February, two months after Fintiv sued Apple, federal prosecutors in Maine indicted Michael Liberty, accusing the founder of Mozido of orchestrating an investment fraud in connection with his fundraising activity around Mozido, the company he once claimed would revolutionize global payments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then right after Liberty's indictment, poof—they rebrand to Fintiv. Pretty convenient timing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then right after Liberty's indictment, poof-they rebrand to Fintiv. Pretty convenient timing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Charlie Wiggs, president of Fintiv, signed the Delaware filing changing Mozidos name to Fintiv a few days after the Securities & Exchange Commission charged Liberty last year of defrauding 200 individual investors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And now Fintiv is using the exact same lawyer, Kasowitz, who represented Liberty. That can't be a coincidence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now Fintiv is using the exact same lawyer, Kasowitz, who represented Liberty. That can't be a coincidence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In its lawsuit against Apple, Fintiv is represented by the law firm headed by Marc Kasowitz, who for years represented Mozido.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It really makes you wonder. And Liberty is still a shareholder in Fintiv today!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really makes you wonder. And Liberty is still a shareholder in Fintiv today!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Liberty, who has pleaded not guilty to the criminal charges filed against him and has previously denied wrongdoing, is one of Fintivs shareholders.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Alongside Wellington Management investors. So he's still involved, even after everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alongside Wellington Management investors. So he's still involved, even after everything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Other shareholders include funds managed by financial giant Wellington Management and hedge fund legend Julian Robertson.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And get this—Mondo was once valued at $15 billion before it all crashed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And get this-Mondo was once valued at fifteen dollars billion before it all crashed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Mozido raised $300 million from big investors to build a mobile payments company and was valued at about $5.6 billion when it purchased PayEase, a Chinese payment processor that generated the vast majority of Mozidos revenue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Then it got sold to PayEase, which Apple later bought. So there's this weird connection back to Apple now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Then it got sold to PayEase, which Apple later bought. So there's this weird connection back to Apple now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Mozido raised $300 million from big investors to build a mobile payments company and was valued at about $5.6 billion when it purchased PayEase, a Chinese payment processor that generated the vast majority of Mozidos revenue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And Salume's out here saying they're "deeply committed to building a better future."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And Salume's out here saying they're deeply committed to building a better future.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: While also, you know, actively litigating where necessary. Sounds familiar.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: While also, you know, actively litigating where necessary. Sounds familiar.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There are other companies using our technology without a license so part of the task of our board is to protect the value of the investors in the company and we do have a strategy, not for lawsuits but for licenses a last resort is a lawsuit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's like a total makeover, but the same people are pulling the strings behind the curtain.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like a total makeover, but the same people are pulling the strings behind the curtain.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Mike Love, who played a big management role at Mozido for years and worked closely with Liberty, is a director of Fintiv. So is Michael Libertys cousin, Stan Liberty.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the shadowy past isn't staying in the past.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the shadowy past isn't staying in the past.

artist_script:
HostA: Fintiv, the social media giant, is suing Apple, right? But their past as Mondo is just wild.
HostB: Oh, absolutely. Mondo, that was the mobile payments company with all the fraud, wasn't it?
HostA: Yeah, over 500 investors got defrauded according to the SEC. And CEO Adolfo Salume admitted to it.
HostB: Wait, and then they had that CFO, Michael Liberty, who was accused of diverting funds for personal use. That’s just… wow.
HostA: Exactly. And then right after Liberty's indictment, poof—they rebrand to Fintiv. Pretty convenient timing.
HostB: And now Fintiv is using the exact same lawyer, Kasowitz, who represented Liberty. That can't be a coincidence.
HostA: It really makes you wonder. And Liberty is still a shareholder in Fintiv today!
HostB: Alongside Wellington Management investors. So he’s still involved, even after everything.
HostA: And get this—Mondo was once valued at $15 billion before it all crashed.
HostB: Then it got sold to PayEase, which Apple later bought. So there's this weird connection back to Apple now.
HostA: Right? And Salume’s out here saying they’re “deeply committed to building a better future.”
HostB: While also, you know, actively litigating where necessary. Sounds familiar.
HostA: It’s like a total makeover, but the same people are pulling the strings behind the curtain.
HostB: Yeah, the shadowy past isn’t staying in the past.
